Award.AwardTitle: Wideband Silicon-Based Receivers for RF/Microwave Spectrum Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Intellectual Merit
Cognitive radio systems offer the opportunity to use dynamic spectrum management techniques to adapt to immediate local spectrum availability over huge swaths of spectrum when the primary users are not present. The objective of this research is to develop a unique wideband silicon-based spectrum sensing receiver for cognitive radios. With respect to intellectual merit, the proposed receiver enables spectrum sensing over multi-octave radio/microwave frequency range without the need for any complex tunable image-reject filter and a broadband frequency synthesizer to drastically reduce the power consumption and the complexity of the receiver. The realization of this receiver is possible by two-step down conversion and employing a narrowband frequency synthesizer, an integer frequency divider and switchable harmonic mixers in the front-end architecture. Given the wide variations in signal bandwidth and formats that must be reliably sensed, a type of programmable energy detection method is employed to further relax challenging requirements for cognitive radio front-ends.
Broader Impact
With respect to broader impact, simple implementation, miniaturization and low power consumption of wideband spectrum sensing receivers are essential features for cognitive radios operating in a battery-powered environment for applications including man-portable military radios, avionics, electronic warfare, eavesdropping, surveillance and commercial wireless mobile systems. The results of the project will advance microwave integrated circuits and wireless communication fields. The proposed project allows talented students to train in microwave integrated circuits and wireless communications through a variety of research, and educational/outreach activities. Educational opportunities for under-represented groups will be explored by (1) attending annual Electrical and Computer Engineering?Unplugged program and Society of Women Engineers summer camp to inspire high school and women students to join the engineering program, and (2) collaborating with Enrichment Experience Engineering program at Texas A&M University to provide workshops for minority high school teachers in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the life of this award, two major goals were targeted, (1) implementation of CMOS wideband wireless receivers with immense tuning capability and strong interferer resilience, and (2) realization of CMOS spectrum sensing units which function based on either effective signal energy/ feature detection or system group delay engineering. 

Two categories of interferer-resilient wideband CMOS receivers were realized. The first one designed to cover the entire band of the cognitive radio spectrum has an inherent wideband Cartesian feedback path to treat the targeted in-band interfere as a common mode signal and reject it through the feedback loop effectively improving the linearity of the wideband receiver. The second one designed to cover the first UWB band for wireless communications uses a separate interferer detector path aside the main receiver path to automatically detect the existing out-of-band interferers using a group delay engineered filter and then adjust the center frequencies of up to three high-Q notch filter in the main receive oath accordingly to suppress out-of-band interferes and effectively improve the receiver linearity.

Also, two categories of CMOS spectrum sensing units for cognitive radios were realized. The first one was based on quasi-cyclostationary feature detection of the received signal based on both energy and feature detection and can take advantage of both methods to reach a fast and accurate decision without the need for an analog-to-digital converter for decision making. The second one was based on real time spectrum sensing which can be useful for cognitive radio (CR) devices to detect primary signals without the need for a receiver, reducing complexity and false detection. The proposed CMOS phaser (temporal frequency dispersion unit) separated different frequency components of a modulated signal in time domain by assigning different delays to them using a group delay engineered filter and was the first real time spectrum sensor applicable to radio frequency integrated circuit area.

The implemented interferer-tolerant wideband CMOS receivers and spectrum sensing units represent the possibility of integrated front-end realization for future generation of cognitive and software-defined radios which are required to function over a very wide frequency range in a hostile environment with strong in-band/out-if-band interferes. Regarding development of human resources, two Ph.D. students were able to gain experience in integrated RF/microwave circuit design along with performing related electrical measurements which made them prepared to tackle complex projects in real world. One Ph.D. student was fully devoted to this project and is planning to graduate soon. A number of journal and conference papers were published in prestigious IEEE Transactions of Microwave Theory and Techniques and presented in IEEE RFIC Symposium, respectively.
